Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Scalable Processing of Novel Multi-scale Hybrid Composites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary research objective of the Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant is to establish the processing science for an environmentally friendly and scalable processing approach toward integrating carbon nanotubes with conventional micron-sized advanced fiber reinforcement to create novel multi-scale hybrid micro/nanocomposites. The selective and intelligent integration of carbon nanotubes by hybridizing with micron-sized textile fibers enables the unique opportunity to form local multi-scale reinforcement architectures for the tailoring of both mechanical and physical properties. Preliminary research has established an efficient technique for producing extremely stable aqueous suspensions of highly dispersed carbon nanotubes in a single processing step. Through selective chemical functionalization of the nanotubes and controlled deposition onto carbon fibers it has been demonstrated that carbon nanotubes can fully penetrate fiber bundles and form chemical bonds with the fiber surface. Advanced composite materials produced from the multi-scale hybrids show remarkable improvements in shear strength and fracture toughness. The significance of the processing approach is that it allows precise control over the purity, structure and chemical functionality of the nanoscale precursor materials. The process is also carried-out under ambient conditions and is industrially scalable for future applications.

If successful, the results of this research will expand the science-base for the manufacturing of nanostructured materials and understanding the basic interrelationship between manufacturing process parameters, the resulting micro- and nano-structure, and the material properties. Environmentally-friendly and cost-effective means for manufacturing carbon nanotube-based composites have the potential to dramatically enhance the large scale applications of structural and functional nanocomposites. Ultimately a fundamental knowledge of the processing-structure-property relationships will enable the nanoscale design of multifunctional nanostructured materials for new applications. The research will provide potential enabling capabilities towards the integration of adaptive, sensory, active and energy storage capabilities of nanostructures within structural materials. The educational plan involves a synergistic undergraduate research and design project to develop a lab-scale pilot facility for continuous deposition. A working pilot facility will then be constructed as a follow-on senior research project. As part of the CAREER educational plan the PI intends to extend a nanotechnology course module to reach-out to local high schools to help to build the pipeline of engineers interested in careers in materials and nanotechnology.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The key outcomes of the Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant established an environmentally friendly and scalable electrophoretic deposition (EPD) processing approach toward integrating carbon nanotubes with conventional micron-sized advanced fiber reinforcement to create novel multi-scale hybrid micro/nanocomposites. Through the course of this research, the fundamental processing-structure-property relations have been established. The EPD technique creates functional coatings on fibers and it was demonstrated that the properties of advanced composites can be significantly improved. In addition, the EPD technique was applied to conventional textile fabric and the coated fibers are soft to the touch and may be utilized in future smart garments. These textile-based sensors have been examined for applications in pressure and deformation sensing. Intellectual Merit: The selective and intelligent integration of carbon nanotubes by hybridizing with micron-sized textile fibers enables the unique opportunity to form local multi-scale reinforcement architectures for the tailoring mechanical and physical properties. Through selective chemical functionalization of the nanotubes and controlled deposition onto fibers, carbon nanotubes can fully penetrate fiber bundles and form chemical bonds with the fiber surface. The significance of the processing approach is that it allows precise control over the purity, structure and chemical functionality of the nanoscale precursor materials. The process is also carried-out under ambient conditions and is industrially scalable for future applications. Advanced composite materials produced from the multi-scale hybrids show remarkable improvements in shear strength and fracture toughness. The technique has been applied to a wide range of other natural and synthetic fibers and has been utilized to create extremely sensitive sensors used for smart garments. The resulting fabric sensor is soft to the touch and breathable. Broader Impacts: Research results have expanded the science-base for the manufacturing of nanostructured materials and understanding the basic interrelationship between manufacturing process parameters, the resulting micro- and nano-structure, and the material properties. Environmentally friendly and cost-effective means for manufacturing carbon nanotube-based composites and smart garment sensors have the potential to dramatically enhance the large-scale applications of structural and functional nanocomposites. This research provides potential enabling capabilities towards the integration of adaptive, sensory, active and energy storage capabilities of nanostructures within structural materials. The educational outcomes included involvement of five undergraduate students in research and design projects and four graduate students. Educational outreach included the development of a composites and smart garment module included in high-school outreach and education of the broader public. The technology developed under this grant is actively being commercialized.


Last Modified: 12/29/2019
Modified by: Erik T Thostenson
